<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Adds the values in rs1 and rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] add rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Adds the immediate value imm to rs1, stores the result in rd.[/INST] addi rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Subtracts the value in rs2 from rs1, stores the result in rd.[/INST] sub rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Multiplies the values in two registers (rs1, rs2) and stores the result in rd.[/INST] mul rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Divides the value in rs1 by the value in rs2 and stores the quotient in rd.[/INST] div rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
divides the value in rs1 by the value in rs2 and stores the remainder of the division in rd.[/INST] rem rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Negates the value in rs, storing the result in rd.[/INST] neg rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Adds the values in registers rs1 and rs2 (as 32-bit integers), then writes the lower 32 bits of the result into rd, sign-extended to 64 bits in RV64.[/INST] addw rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Negates the word in rs, storing the result in rd.[/INST] negw rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise XOR on rs1 and rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] xor rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise OR on rs1 and rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] or rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise AND on rs1 and rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] and rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise XOR on rs1 and the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] xori rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise OR on rs1 and the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] ori rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs a bitwise AND on rs1 and the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] andi rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Performs bitwise NOT on rs, storing the result in rd.[/INST] not rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 left logically by the amount specified in rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] sll rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 right logically by the amount specified in rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] srl rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 right arithmetically by the amount specified in rs2, stores the result in rd.[/INST] sra rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than rs2, otherwise sets rd to 0.[/INST] slt rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than rs2, unsigned comparison, otherwise sets rd to 0.[/INST] sltu rd, rs1, rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 left logically by the amount specified in the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] slli rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 right logically by the amount specified in the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] srli rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Shifts rs1 right arithmetically by the amount specified in the immediate value imm, stores the result in rd.[/INST] srai rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than the immediate value imm, otherwise sets rd to 0.[/INST] slti rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than the immediate value imm, unsigned comparison, otherwise sets rd to 0.[/INST] sltiu rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads an immediate value into rd.[/INST] li rd, immediate</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Copies the value from rs to rd.[/INST] mv rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sign-extends the word in rs into rd.[/INST] sext.w rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs equals zero; else sets to 0.[/INST] seqz rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs is not zero; else sets to 0.[/INST] snez rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs is less than zero; else sets to 0.[/INST] sltz rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs is greater than zero; else sets to 0.[/INST] sgtz rd, rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Adds two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fadd.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Subtracts two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fsub.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Multiplies two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fmul.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Divides two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fdiv.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Calculates the square root of a single-precision floating-point number.[/INST] fsqrt.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Computes the minimum of two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fmin.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Computes the maximum of two single-precision floating-point numbers.[/INST] fmax.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Copies the sign of rs2 to rs1 in single-precision.[/INST] fsgnj.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Negates the sign of rs2 and applies it to rs1 in single-precision.[/INST] fsgnjn.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
XORs the signs of rs1 and rs2, applying the result to rd in single-precision.[/INST] fsgnjx.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Converts a single-precision floating-point number to a 32-bit integer.[/INST] fcvt.w.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Converts a 32-bit integer to a single-precision floating-point number.[/INST] fcvt.s.w</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Moves single-precision floating-point bits to an integer register.[/INST] fmv.x.w</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Moves integer bits to a single-precision floating-point register.[/INST] fmv.w.x</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a byte from memory at address rs1 + offset, sign-extends it, and stores the result in rd.[/INST] lb rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a halfword from memory at address rs1 + offset, sign-extends it, and stores the result in rd.[/INST] lh rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a word from memory at address rs1 + offset and stores it in rd.[/INST] lw rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a byte from memory at address rs1 + offset, zero-extends it, and stores the result in rd.[/INST] lbu rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a halfword from memory at address rs1 + offset, zero-extends it, and stores the result in rd.[/INST] lhu rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores the lowest byte of rs2 into memory at address rs1 + offset.[/INST] sb rs2, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores the lowest halfword of rs2 into memory at address rs1 + offset.[/INST] sh rs2, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores the word in rs2 into memory at address rs1 + offset.[/INST] sw rs2, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a doubleword (64-bit) from memory at the address formed by adding offset to rs1 into rd.[/INST] ld rd, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores the doubleword (64-bit) in rs2 into memory at the address formed by adding offset to rs1.[/INST] sd rs2, offset(rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads the address of a symbol into register rd.[/INST] la rd, symbol</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a single-precision floating-point number from memory into a floating-point register rd.[/INST] flw</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores a single-precision floating-point number from a floating-point register rs2 into memory.[/INST] fsw</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Loads a double-precision floating-point number from memory into a floating-point register rd.[/INST] fld</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Stores a double-precision floating-point number from a floating-point register rs2 into memory.[/INST] fsd</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Orders memory operations as seen by other harts and external devices.[/INST] fence</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Ensures that all previous instruction writes are observed before any subsequent instructions are fetched.[/INST] fence.i</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if the values in rs1 and rs2 are equal.[/INST] beq rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if the values in rs1 and rs2 are not equal.[/INST] bne rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if rs1 is less than rs2, using signed comparison.[/INST] blt rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if rs1 is greater than or equal to rs2, using signed comparison.[/INST] bge rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if rs1 is less than rs2, using unsigned comparison.[/INST] bltu rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Branches to PC + offset if rs1 is greater than or equal to rs2, using unsigned comparison.[/INST] bgeu rs1, rs2, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Jumps to PC + offset and stores the return address (PC + 4) in rd.[/INST] jal rd, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Jumps to (rs1 + offset) and stores the return address (PC + 4) in rd. The target address is aligned to a word boundary.[/INST] jalr rd, rs1, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Jumps to PC + offset if the value in rs is zero.[/INST] beqz rs, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Jumps to PC + offset if the value in rs is not zero.[/INST] bnez rs, offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Unconditionally jumps to PC + offset.[/INST] j offset</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Unconditionally jumps to the address contained in rs.[/INST] jr rs</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Returns from a subroutine by jumping to the address contained in the link register x1.[/INST] ret</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if single-precision floating-point numbers in rs1 and rs2 are equal, else 0.[/INST] feq.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than rs2 in single-precision.[/INST] flt.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than or equal to rs2 in single-precision.[/INST] fle.s</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if double-precision floating-point numbers in rs1 and rs2 are equal, else 0.[/INST] feq.d</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than rs2 in double-precision, else 0.[/INST] flt.d</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Sets rd to 1 if rs1 is less than or equal to rs2 in double-precision, else 0.[/INST] fle.d</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRRC instruction clears bits of the speciﬁed CSR. It can be used to simply read a CSR without updating it. If ( rs1) is x0, then no update to the CSR will occur. The previous value of the CSR is copied to the destination register and then some selected bits of the CSR are cleared to 0, the value in ( rs1) is used as a bit mask to select which bits are to be cleared in the CSR. Other bits are unchanged. This is an atomic operation.[/INST] csrrc rd, csr, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRR instruction is used to read the value of CSR. The previous value of the CSR is copied to the destination register. This is an atomic read operation.[/INST] csrr rd, csr</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The previous value of the CSR is copied to destination register and the value of the source register (rs1) is copied to the CSR, this is an atomic write operation. To read a CSR without writing to it, the source register ( rs1) can be speciﬁed as x0. To write a CSR without reading it, the destination register ( rd) can be speciﬁed as x0. This is an atomic operation.[/INST] csrrw rd, csr, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRRS instruction can be used to simply read a CSR without updating it. If ( rs1)is x0, then no update to the CSR will occur. The previous value of the CSR is copied to the destination register and then some selected bits of the CSR are set to 0. The value in ( rs1) is used as a bit mask to select which bits are to be set in the CSR. Other bits are unchanged. This is an atomic operation.[/INST] csrrs rd, csr, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRRCI instruction makes bits[4:0] in any CSR particularly easy to modify. The previous value of the CSR is copied to the destination register and then the CSR is cleared using immediate value. The 5-bit ﬁeld that is normally used for rs1is zero-extended and used as the source value that is moved into the CSR. This is an atomic operation. 19[/INST] csrrci rd, csr, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRRSI instruction makes bits[4:0] in any CSR particularly easy to set to “1” . The previous value of the CSR is copied to the destination register and then some selected bits of the CSR are set to 1. The 5-bit ﬁeld that is normally used for rs1is zero-extended and used as a bit mask to select which bits are to be set in the CSR. This is an atomic operation.[/INST] csrrsi rd, csr, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The CSRRWI is a variant of the CSRRW instruction, which is used to overwrite to a csr with the speciﬁed immediate value. The previous valueof the csr is copied to the destination register and then the entire csr is written to. The 5-bit ﬁeld that is usually used for source register ( rs1) is 20 zero-extended and used as the immediate value that is moved into the register. This is an atomic operation.[/INST] csrrwi rd, csr, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The LUIinstruction, copies the immediate value to the upper 20 bits of the destination register (rd). The lower 12 bits of the destination register is reset to zero. This instruction is usually used, when a register needs to be populated with a large value. The immediate value can be represented in hexadecimal or decimal format. In a RV64 systems, the most signiﬁcant bit is sign extended to ﬁll the most signiﬁcant 32 bits (bits 63 - 32) 2.1.2.1. The destination registers can be any of the[/INST] lui rd, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
AUIPC is used to build pc-relative addresses. AUIPC forms a 32-bit temporary oﬀset, by adding the 20-bit immediate value to the upper 20 bits of temporary oﬀset, ﬁlling in the lower 12 bits with zeros. The temporary oﬀset is added to the pc, to form the pc-relative address. The result is placed in the destination register ( rd). In a 64 bit architecture, the temporary oﬀset is sign extended and added to pc. The destination registers can be any of the 31 base registers. The x0 register can be used as a source register only, but not as a destination register.[/INST] auipc rd, imm 35</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
A 32-bit value is fetched from memory and moved into destination register, the memory address is formed by adding the oﬀset to the contents of ( rs1). 32-bit registers machine don’t require either signextension or zeroextension is necessary for value that is already 32 bits wide, therefore the “signed load” instruction LWdoes the same thing as the “unsigned load” instruction LWU, making LWUredundant. This instruction is available only for 64-bit and 128-bit machines.[/INST] lwu rd, offset( rs1)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SEXT.W is an assembler pseudo-instruction which is available only for 64-bit and 128-bit machines. This instruction sign extends the lower 32 bits of value in rs1to 64 or 128 bits with the result being placed in the register rd.SEXT.W is useful when a 32-bit signed value must be extended to a larger value on 64-bit or 128-bit machine.[/INST] sext.w rd, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
NEGinstruction arithmetically negates the contents of rs1and places the result in register rd. This instruction translates to instruction Subtraction (SUB) where the contents of rs1is subtracted from zero.[/INST] neg rd, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
RISC-V provides a simple pseudo-assembler instruction, SEQZ , to check if the contents of the register rs1, is zero or not. Indication is provided by a single bit value 0 if the register content is not 0 or value 1, if the register content is zero. SEQZ performs an unsigned comparison against 1. Since the comparison is unsigned, the only value less than 1 is 0. Hence if the comparison holds true, register rs1must contain 0.[/INST] seqz rd,rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SNEZ is a pseudo-assembler instruction that is used to check if the contents of a rs1, is a non-zero value. This instruction sets value of register rdto 1 if the rs1is a non-zero value or sets rdto 0 otherwise. This instruction is implemented with an unsigned comparison against 0 using its base instruction SLTU . Since it is an unsigned comparison, the only value less than 0 is 0 itself. Therefore, if the less-than condition holds, the value in rs1must not be 0.[/INST] snez rd,rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SLTZ is a signed pseudo-assembler instruction which translates to SLT, examines if the value in register rs1is less than zero. If register value found to be less than zero, a value 1 is stored in register rd. Otherwise the value 0 is stored.[/INST] sltz rd,rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SGTZ is a signed pseudo-assembler instruction which examines if the value in register rs1is greater than zero. If found true, value 1 is stored to register ( rd) or value 0 is stored otherwise.[/INST] sgtz rd,rs1 sltrd, x0, rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SRAdirective performs an arithmetic shift right by 0 to 32 places. The vacated bits at the most signiﬁcant end are ﬁlled with zeros if the original value (the source operand) was positive. The vacated bits are ﬁlled with ones if the original value was negative. This is known as “sign extending” because the most signiﬁcant bit of the original value is the sign bit for 2’s complement numbers, i.e. 0 for positive and 1 for negative numbers. Arithmetic shifting therefore preserves the sign of numbers.[/INST] sra rd, rs1,rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
SRAI is arithmetic shift right of a number by ’N’ places. The vacated bits at the most signiﬁcant end are ﬁlled with value of sign bit (0 for +ve sign and 1 for -ve sign). <s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
ASLTI is a signed comparison between contents of the speciﬁed registers. If the value in register is less than the immediate value, value 1 is stored in destination register, otherwise, value 0 is stored in the destination register.[/INST] slti rd, rs1, imm</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

Overﬂows are ignored and the lower 32 bits of result is written to the destination register.[/INST] add rd, rs1,rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

The source and destination registers can be any of the 31 base registers. The x0 register can be used as a source register only, but not as a destination register. The overﬂows as well as borrow are ignored and the lower 32 bits of result is written to the destination register.[/INST] sub rd, rs1,rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
MULcalculates the product of two XLEN-bit operands in the source registers 1 and 2 ( rs1,rs2). This instruction stores the less signiﬁcant part of the result in the destination register and any overﬂow is ignored.[/INST] mul rd, rs1,rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
MULH calculates the product of signed multiplier and signed multiplicand (present in the two source registers speciﬁed respectively), and places the upper XLEN bits of the full 2*XLEN product, into the destination register. <s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The ECALL instruction is used to implement system calls. System calls are subroutine calls made from a lower privilege code to a higher privilege code. The execution happens in the higher privilege level and result is given back to the lower privilege code. Once the desired operation is over, the control returns back to the lower privilege level. Generally, if an operation needs to be done at a higher privilege level, ECALL is used. For example, the implementations of libraries for FILE operations in a Unix operating system, uses ECALL. On execution of ECALL, one of the following exception arise: •Environment Call from User Mode •Environment Call from Supervisor Mode •Environment Call from Machine Mode As described in the section “mcause”, the above exceptions have a dedicated exception code. The trap handler in higher privilege level handles the exception and redirects the call to the corresponding subroutine. The arguments are passed through argument registers ( ai) and result is saved in Saved register ( si). 80[/INST] ecall</s>

As RISC-V has no arithmetic ﬂags (i.e., carry, overﬂow, zero, sign ﬂags), any arithmetic operation whose destination register is x0 will endup as a no operation instruction regardless of the source registers.[/INST] nop 81</s>

The return will be eﬀected by copying the saved program counter from mepc to the Program Counter (pc).[/INST] MRET</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Usage: Lets say pcis at 0x80000000. After execution of below instruction. nop # pc←−pc+ 2 pcbecomes 0x80000002. The state of the machine is unchanged. 82 6chapter Trap’s in RISC-V Trap is a speciﬁc scenario caused by a exceptional condition or interrupt. In RISC-V, the term trap refers to, transfer of control to a trap handler caused either by an exception or an interrupt. Exception is an unusual condition occurring at run time of an instruction in the current RISC- V hart. An exception disrupts the normal ﬂow of instruction execution. Exceptions are usually synchronous. Interrupts are another form of a trap, where the origin of interrupt is from Timer or peripherals. Interrupt is a scenario designed to service a speciﬁc external input. All the Traps can be handled or ignored. It is upto the software to decide. A “trap handler” is a subroutine that handles the trap in a software. The way of handling a trap is left to the software designer and varies from one type of trap to another.[/INST] nop 81</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
The BEQinstruction compares contents of ( rs1) is compared to the contents of ( rs2). If equal, control jumps. The target address is given as a PC-relative oﬀset. <s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Provides a hint to the implementation that the current hart can be stalled until an interrupt might need servicing. Execution of the WFI instruction can also be used to inform the hardware platform that suitable interrupts should preferentially be routed to this hart. WFI is available in all privileged modes, and optionally available to U-mode. This instruction may raise an illegal instruction exception when TW=1 in mstatus.[/INST] wfi</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Guarantees that any previous stores already visible to the current RISC-V hart are ordered before all subsequent implicit references from that hart to the memory-management data structures. The SFENCE.VMA is used to flush any local hardware caches related to address translation. It is specified as a fence rather than a TLB flush to provide cleaner semantics with respect to which instructions are affected by the flush operation and to support a wider variety of dynamic caching structures and memory-management schemes. SFENCE.VMA is also used by higher privilege levels to synchronize page table writes and the address translation hardware.[/INST] sfence.vma</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Used to order device I/O and memory accesses as viewed by other RISC-V harts and external devices or coprocessors. Any combination of device input (I), device output (O), memory reads ®, and memory writes (W) may be ordered with respect to any combination of the same. Informally, no other RISC-V hart or external device can observe any operation in the successor set following a FENCE before any operation in the predecessor set preceding the FENCE.[/INST] fence pred, succ</s>

Atomically swaps values in the CSRs and integer registers. CSRRW reads the old value of the CSR, zero-extends the value to XLEN bits, then writes it to integer register rd. The initial value in rs1 is written to the CSR. If rd=x0, then the instruction shall not read the CSR and shall not cause any of the side effects that might occur on a CSR read.[/INST] csrrw rd,offset,rs1</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Reads the value of the CSR, zero-extends the value to XLEN bits, and writes it to integer register rd. The initial value in integer register rs1 is treated as a bit mask that specifies bit positions to be set in the CSR. Any bit that is high in rs1 will cause the corresponding bit to be set in the CSR, if that CSR bit is writable. Other bits in the CSR are unaffected (though CSRs might have side effects when written).[/INST] csrrs rd,offset,rs1</s>

Execution of the WFI instruction can also be used to inform the hardware platform that suitable interrupts should preferentially be routed to this hart. <s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Guarantees that any previous stores already visible to the current RISC-V hart are ordered before all subsequent implicit references from that hart to the memory-management data structures. The SFENCE.VMA is used to flush any local hardware caches related to address translation. It is specified as a fence rather than a TLB flush to provide cleaner semantics with respect to which instructions are affected by the flush operation and to support a wider variety of dynamic caching structures and memory-management schemes. SFENCE.VMA is also used by higher privilege levels to synchronize page table writes and the address translation hardware.[/INST] sfence.vma rs1,rs2</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Used to order device I/O and memory accesses as viewed by other RISC-V harts and external devices or coprocessors. Any combination of device input (I), device output (O), memory reads ®, and memory writes (W) may be ordered with respect to any combination of the same. Informally, no other RISC-V hart or external device can observe any operation in the successor set following a FENCE before any operation in the predecessor set preceding the FENCE.[/INST] Fence(pred, succ)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Atomically swaps values in the CSRs and integer registers. CSRRW reads the old value of the CSR, zero-extends the value to XLEN bits, then writes it to integer register rd. The initial value in rs1 is written to the CSR. If rd=x0, then the instruction shall not read the CSR and shall not cause any of the side effects that might occur on a CSR read.[/INST] t = CSRs[csr]; CSRs[csr] = x[rs1]; x[rd] = t</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Reads the value of the CSR, zero-extends the value to XLEN bits, and writes it to integer register rd. The initial value in integer register rs1 is treated as a bit mask that specifies bit positions to be set in the CSR. Any bit that is high in rs1 will cause the corresponding bit to be set in the CSR, if that CSR bit is writable. Other bits in the CSR are unaffected (though CSRs might have side effects when written).[/INST] t = CSRs[csr]; CSRs[csr] = t | x[rs1]; x[rd] = t</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Reads the value of the CSR, zero-extends the value to XLEN bits, and writes it to integer register rd. The initial value in integer register rs1 is treated as a bit mask that specifies bit positions to be cleared in the CSR. Any bit that is high in rs1 will cause the corresponding bit to be cleared in the CSR, if that CSR bit is writable. Other bits in the CSR are unaffected.[/INST] t = CSRs[csr]; CSRs[csr] = t &∼x[rs1]; x[rd] = t</s>

When executed in U-mode, S-mode, or M-mode, it generates an environment-call-from-U-mode exception, environment-call-from-S-mode exception, or environment-call-from-M-mode exception, respectively, and performs no other operation.[/INST] RaiseException(EnvironmentCall)</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Provides a hint to the implementation that the current hart can be stalled until an interrupt might need servicing. Execution of the WFI instruction can also be used to inform the hardware platform that suitable interrupts should preferentially be routed to this hart. WFI is available in all privileged modes, and optionally available to U-mode. This instruction may raise an illegal instruction exception when TW=1 in mstatus.[/INST] while (noInterruptsPending) idle</s>

<s>[INST] Write the RISC-V assembly instruction for the following operation:
Guarantees that any previous stores already visible to the current RISC-V hart are ordered before all subsequent implicit references from that hart to the memory-management data structures. The SFENCE.VMA is used to flush any local hardware caches related to address translation. It is specified as a fence rather than a TLB flush to provide cleaner semantics with respect to which instructions are affected by the flush operation and to support a wider variety of dynamic caching structures and memory-management schemes. SFENCE.VMA is also used by higher privilege levels to synchronize page table writes and the address translation hardware.[/INST] Fence(Store, AddressTranslation)</s>
